Class ManhattanDistanceMetric

Manhattan distance metric.

The Manhattan distance is simply the sum total of all of the distances in each dimension. Also known as the taxicab distance, rectilinear distance, L1 distance or L1 norm.

Use the default constructor for classical Manhattan Distance. Optionally the constructor can be provided with a two coefficients and a constant that can be used to modify/distort distance measures. These are:

matchDistanceCoeff: When comparing two positions in the same dimension the distance between those two position is multiplied by this coefficient.

mismatchDistanceCoeff, mismatchDistanceConstant: When comparing two coordinates where one describes a position in a given dimension and the other does not then the second coordinate is assumed to be at position zero in that dimension. However, the resulting distance is multiplied by this coefficient and mismatchDistanceConstant is added, therefore allowing matches and mismatches to be weighted differently, e.g. more emphasis can be placed on mismatches (and therefore network topology). If mismatchDistanceCoeff is zero and mismatchDistanceConstant is non-zero then the distance of mismatches is a fixed value.

The two coefficients and constant allow the following schemes:

  1. Classical Manhattan distance.
  2. Topology only distance metric (ignore connections weights).
  3. Equivalent of genome distance in Original NEAT (O-NEAT). This is actually a mix of (1) and (2).

ManhattanDistanceMetric()

Constructs using default weightings for comparisons on matching and mismatching dimensions. Classical Manhattan Distance.

Declaration

| Improve this Doc View Source

ManhattanDistanceMetric(double, double, double)

Constructs using the provided weightings for comparisons on matching and mismatching dimensions.

Declaration
public ManhattanDistanceMetric(double matchDistanceCoeff, double mismatchDistanceCoeff, double mismatchDistanceConstant)
Parameters
Type Name Description
double matchDistanceCoeff

A coefficient to applied to the distance obtained from two coordinates that both describe a position in a given dimension.
double mismatchDistanceCoeff

A coefficient applied to the distance obtained from two coordinates where only one of the coordinates describes a position in a given dimension. The other point is taken to be at position zero in that dimension.
double mismatchDistanceConstant

A constant that is added to the distance where only one of the coordinates describes a position in a given dimension. This adds extra emphasis to distance when comparing coordinates that exist in different dimensions.

CalculateCentroid(ReadOnlySpan<ConnectionGenes<double>>)

Calculates the centroid for the given set of points.

Declaration
public ConnectionGenes<double> CalculateCentroid(ReadOnlySpan<ConnectionGenes<double>> points)
Parameters
Type Name Description
ReadOnlySpan<ConnectionGenes<double>> points
Returns
Type Description
ConnectionGenes<double>

A new instance of ConnectionGenes<T>.
Remarks

The centroid is a central position within a set of points that minimizes the sum of the squared distance between each of those points and the centroid. As such it can also be thought of as being representative of the set of points.

The centroid calculation is dependent on the distance metric, hence this method is defined on IDistanceMetric<T>. For some distance metrics the centroid may not be a unique point, in those cases one of the possible centroids is returned.

A centroid is used in k-means clustering to define the centre of a cluster.
